bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. Arthur S. Griswold, January 27, 1951

div1.p: Hench thanks Mrs. Griswold for her contribution to the Reed Memorial Association and informs her that most of the association's funds are used to support Reed's daughter.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mrs. Arthur S. Griswold, January 27, 1951
div1.opener:
January 27, 1951
Mrs. Arthur S. Griswold
5015 Pon Valley
Bloomfield Hills, Michigan
My dear Mrs. Griswold:
div1.p:
I went to Europe late in September, came home for just a few days,
during which time I was extremely busy and was not able to touch my cor-
respondence, then went back to Europe again and have just returned home. I
regret very much indeed that I have not acknowledged your kind letter of
October 13 with your generous contribution of $25 to the Walter Reed Memorial
Foundation.

At the moment there is actually no Walter Reed Memorial Founda-
tion but there is a Walter Reed Memorial Association. I am Vice-President
of the Board of Managers. The other members of the Board of Managers are
distinguished and well-known Washington citizens. Two or three have been
retired major generals, close friends of Walter Reed and the Surgeon General
of the Army is also a member.

The fund is, at the moment, too small to accomplish much in the
way of a memorial. The income from most of the fund has been used for a
number of years to help support Walter Reed's widow who lived to the un-
usual age of 90 and died just a few months ago. Her daughter, Blossom
(Walter Reed's daughter) through these long years took devoted care of
her disabled mother. There were many unusual expenses over a long period
of years and most of the income from the Walter Reed Memorial Trust Fund
is now being given to the daughter for her support. If one were to have
asked Walter Reed “How can we honor you, sir?” I am sure that his first
thought would have been for the comfort of his wife and daughter. That
is what we have done to date. If and as the fund can be increased materially,
we have hopes for some other type of a living memorial to Walter Reed.

I am sending your generous donation to Colonel Siler, the new
President of the Walter Reed Memorial Association, who just took office
on the death of the beloved General Jefferson Randolph Kean who was Walter
Reed's right-hand man in Cuba and a very close friend of the Reed family
through the years. May Colonel Siler and I assume that unless you let us
hear otherwise, you approve my sending this check to him. But if you have
some other thought in mind, we shall act accordingly.

Permit me to thank you also for graciously sending to me the
most interesting book of the Washington murals. I am very glad to have
this.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
